div.p:
The SUMMARY LIGHT interface is a single-server view that provides main system metrics information from one view, such as CPU utilization, memory and processes statistics.
This dashboard provides an easy and fast view of key system metrics of your server.

The WALL OF PERFORMANCE interface is a multi-server advanced view that proposes from a single page most system metrics activity in single forms visualizations.
Each metric can be activated to access within the same page time oriented advanced charts.
This dashboard can be easily cloned to customize the list of servers to be monitored, and will be usable anywhere in Splunk, in or out of the Nmon App.

search.query: | inputlookup nmon_inventory | search OStype="Solaris" | stats count

h4.i: Data Categories: Explore All / Event Types: nmon:performance (Performance data), nmon:config (Configuration data), nmon:collect (Nmon raw data generation), nmon:processing (Nmon raw data processing) - About Nmon Performance Monitor

div.div:
The Nmon application implements eventtypes to provide an easy and structured access to every piece of data within the app.
On the top most level, the main eventtype provides access to all raw data:

On sub-levels, Top interest eventtypes will contain the performance metrics data (nmon:performance) and configuration data (nmon:config) The nmon:collect eventtype contains information about nmon processes generation that will collect the performance and configuration data on servers. The nmon:processing eventtype contains information about processing steps that converts the nmon data into usable data for Splunk.

In the nmon:performance data, the "key" is the type field.
This field contains the monitor identifier that matches a category of metrics, such as "type=CPU_ALL". (global CPU usage in percentage)
For convenience, main monitors have been categorized into main eventtypes, but on the nmon:performance level any monitor can be filtered adding the "type=xxxx" search.
Note that searching for the CPU_ALL data for example, can be identically achieved by using "eventtype:nmon:performance type=CPU_ALL" or "eventtype:nmon:performance:cpu type=CPU_ALL".

The nmon:performance eventtype contains all the data related to performance metrics of your systems.
In the nmon:performance data, the "key" is the type field.
This field contains the monitor identifier that matches a category of metrics, such as "type=CPU_ALL". (global CPU usage in percentage)
For convenience, main monitors have been categorized into main eventtypes, but on the nmon:performance level any monitor can be filtered adding the "type=xxxx" search.
Note that searching for the CPU_ALL data for example, can be identically achieved by using "eventtype:nmon:performance type=CPU_ALL" or "eventtype:nmon:performance:cpu type=CPU_ALL".

The nmon:config eventtype contains all the data related to the configuration of your systems.
These are the AAA and BBB* sections of nmon raw data, generated during the nmon binary startup.
The events are long multi-lines events stored per host, in default configuration these data will be extracted almost every 2 hours as the data will not change unless a new nmon process gets launched.

The nmon:config data is associated with the generation of the nmon_inventory lookup and the Nmon_Config data model.
The nmon_inventory lookup table is being generated by a scheduled report (which runs by default every hour) that extracts main configuration items (number of CPUs, volume of physical memory...) from the nmon:configuration data over the Nmon_Config data model.
Once the nmon_inventory data has been generated, it is ready to be used and explored within various interfaces.

The nmon:collect eventtype contains all the data related to the nmon processes generation on your systems.
These are the ouput of the input script "nmon_helper.sh" thats gets automatically launched by Splunk when deploying the Nmon App.
By default, the nmon_helper.sh script gets started every minute, its main job is to verify the status of the current nmon process, and start a new one if conditions requires it.
Many nmon starting options can be controlled through the "nmon.conf" configuration file during the deployment of the App, get more information on the online Wiki:

div.a: Online help: manage nmon collection Â»

div.div:
The nmon:processing eventtype contains all the data related to the nmon processing steps that converts nmon data into usable data for Splunk.
These are the ouput of nmon2csv Python and Perl parsers provided within the App.
Every time an existing raw nmon file is updated, or a new one gets created, Splunk will call parsers scripts and generate appropriated data.
Many nmon starting options can be controlled through the "nmon.conf" configuration file during the deployment of the App, get more information on the online Wiki:

single.option: DATE OF FIRST AND LAST PERF EVENT

search.ref: Hosts with data within last 7 days

drilldown.link: search?q=| pivot NMON_Config Nmon_Config dc(hostname) AS "dcount" SPLITROW _time AS _time PERIOD day SORT 0 _time ROWSUMMARY 0 COLSUMMARY 0 NUMCOLS 0 SHOWOTHER 1

search.ref: Number of Errors in Data Processing or Data Collect since last 24 Hours

drilldown.link: search?q=(eventtype=nmon:processing OR eventtype=nmon:collect error) OR (index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd ERROR ExecProcessor nmon) NOT ("There is no python in" OR "python: not found") earliest="-24h" latest="now"

h4.i: Enter Splunk Triggered Alerts for Nmon App - Enter Nmon SAFE CENTER dashboard

search.ref: SAFE CENTER - Number of active CPU alerts
SAFE CENTER - Number of active Real Memory alerts
SAFE CENTER - Number of active Virtual Memory alerts
SAFE CENTER - Number of active FS alerts

span.title:
CPU Utilization statistics in Percentage (%)
â¢ Represents the percentage of CPU system load for all available cores
â¢ Statistics can be returned in global usage or main category: Sys,User,Wait,Idle

CPU Utilization per logical core statistics in Percentage (%)
â¢ Represents the percentage of CPU system load by logical core (lower level of CPU usage details)
â¢ Statistics can be returned in global usage or main category: Sys,User,Wait,Idle

a.span: ALL OS: Percentage of CPU Utilization per logical core

span.title:
CPU Utilization statistics in Percentage (%) for Projects, Zones, Tasks or Users
â¢ Same as 'prstat -J.CPU' (or -Z or -T or -a)
â¢ WLMPROJECTCPU, project name â¢ WLMZONECPU, zone name â¢ WLMTASKCPU, task id â¢ WLMUSERCPU, username

a.span: CPU load for Projects, Tasks, Zones, Users

span.title:
Statistics of Main Processes System Resources Usage
â¢ Get the CPU core utilization of main processes aggregated by Command invocations
â¢ Others Statistics available: Real/Virtual memory usage, minor and major faults and more
â¢ With UARG information, filter PIDs from Command to get accurate measures of complex processes

Search for PIDs, Commands and Full Arguments of Processes
â¢ With UARG, get detailed information about Commands registered: PID, Full arguments and more
â¢ These information can also be very useful within TOP interfaces for accurate analysis

a.span: Search for PIDs, Commands and Arguments

span.title:
Various Kernel File statistics
â¢ Read / Write System calls and other statistics

Kernel Internal Statistics
â¢ RunQueue, Swap-In, pswitch, syscall, fork, exec and more

Solaris Processes Activity Statistics
This interface will return the percentage of time processes have spent in, such as
â¢ % of Time in User / System / mode, % of Time processing system traps
â¢ % of Time waiting for CPU, and more

a.span: Percentage of Time Processes have spent in

span.title:
Various Virtual Memory statistics
â¢ Pageins / Pageout
â¢ Swapins / Swapout
â¢ Minor and Major faults
And more

Real and Virtual Memory Statistics
â¢ Memory Usage in Data Volume (MB) or Percentage
â¢ Specific System Stats (for Linux: Buffers / Cached / Active / Inactive...)

Various Memory Statistics
â¢ Cache Hit Ratio, System Buffer Accesses...

Memory Utilization statistics in Percentage (%) for Projects, Zones, Tasks or Users
â¢ Same as 'prstat -J.MEMORY' (or -Z or -T or -a)
â¢ WLMPROJECTMEM, project name â¢ WLMZONEMEM, zone name â¢ WLMTASKMEM, task id â¢ WLMUSERMEM, username

a.span: Memory load for Projects, Tasks, Zones, Users

span.title:
Transfer Statistics per Disk
â¢ Average data size per block device transfer per disk (KBytes per transfer)

Percentage of Time Busy Disk
â¢ Analyse the Percentage of Time a disk was busy

a.span: The Percentage of time a disk was Busy

span.title:
Disks Read and Write Data rate
â¢ Analyse Disk Read and Write operation Data rate in Kbytes/sec

Disks I/O per second
â¢ Numbers of Input / Output operations per second (formerly IOPS) by disk

(ms) Average service time by disk
â¢ Same as 'sar -d.avserv'
â¢ Same as 'iostat -xn.asvc_t'. For iostat, a disk is referred as a device'

(ms) Average wait time by disk
â¢ Same as 'sar -d.avwait'
â¢ Same as 'iostat -xn.wsvc_t'. For iostat, a disk is referred as a device'

File Systems Percentage Usage
â¢ Percentage usage of different file systems available

a.span: ALL OS: File systems Percentage Usage

span.title:
Network Traffic per interface
â¢ Analyse Traffic Data per interface in Kbps / Mbps / Gbps and per host

Network Packets per interface
â¢ Analyse the Number of Read and Write Network packets per interface and per host

a.span: ALL OS: Read/Write packets per Interface

span.title:
Network Packets in Error per interface
â¢ Analyse the Number of Network packets that in error per interface and per host

Nmon Baseline Analysis
â¢ With the baseline Nmon KV Store, use this interface to analyse historical data and detect key system metrics derivations
â¢ Key system metrics (CPU usage, Real and Virtual Memory, IOPS disk statistics) charted over the baseline
â¢ Optionally chart current statistics over the future baseline and get realtime situation of system resources utilization

CPU Predictive Analysis Interface
â¢ Using the predict Splunk command, this interface will help trying to estimate future CPU load of your systems
â¢ Choose between available algorithms: Local Level (LL), Seasonal Local Level (LLP) and Local Level Trend (LLT)

a.span: Predictive interface, forecast future using predict

span.title:
Nmon Comparison Interface
â¢ Compare System Resources usage between 2 periods, a reference Period and arrival Period
â¢ Choose between Main Monitors: CPU usage (CPU_ALL / LPAR), Memory, I/O, Network
â¢ Evaluate the trend with Evolution Rate and graphical decorations to help instantly discover the comparison result

BubbleChart: TOP hosts CPU Usage
â¢ Evaluate the TOP 100 hosts CPU load represented in Bubble Charts to instantly discover hosts responsible of the global load average
â¢ Evaluate the TOP 20 hosts CPU load represented in d3chart bar chart
â¢ Evaluate the full Statistics table of hosts CPU load with main hosts information

Bullet charts Dashboard: Analysis of main system metrics in bullet charts
â¢ TOP hosts by CPU usage / TOP hosts by physical and virtual memory usage
â¢ TOP Commands (processes) consumming CPU and Memory in your deployment
â¢ Advanced drilldown facilities for insight analysis

a.span: Bullet Chart: TOP Servers / TOP Processes

span.title:
D3chart: Processes CPU and Memory Usage
â¢ Evaluate Processes CPU and Memory usage in d3chart BubbleChart to instantly represent major Command invocations
â¢ Represent this CPU / Memory usage in a d3chart chart over time

D3chart: Solaris Projects / Zones / Tasks / Users CPU and Memory statistics
â¢ Evaluate Major CPU and MEM usage items, choose between available monitors
â¢ Represent this CPU / Memory usage in a d3chart bubblechart and statistic tables

a.span: WLM CPU and Memory Solaris Statistics

span.title:
Hosts Configuration Show Interface
â¢ Explore the raw configuration of hosts
â¢ The full raw host configuration is part of AAA and BBB sections of raw Nmon files

Nmon Configuration Inventory
â¢ Explore the Nmon inventory of known hosts from your system to get valuable information
â¢ Main configuration Items depends on Operating System: type of OS, OS version, CPU / Mem configuration and more

Data Processing Activity: Calendar
Analyse in Heatmap Calendars the Nmon Processing Activity:
â¢ Volume of Raw Data Proceeded (in MB)
â¢ Errors in Data Processing (Count of)
â¢ Time Spent in Data Processing (in Seconds, conversion of NMON files)

Data Performance Activity: Calendar
Analyse in Heatmap Calendars type of Performance Data available for hosts

Application Internal Statistics
â¢ Analyse detailed Nmon Processing Statistics: Conversion of raw Nmon data files
â¢ Get indexes and sourcetypes Statistics
â¢ Get Applications Statistics: Volume of Data indexes, Number of Hits per page

Data Dictionary
â¢ Discover and Explore available data within the Nmon Splunk Application
â¢ Filter relevant Data for AIX, Linux and Solaris systems
â¢ Access to full metric definition: brieve and full description, relevant unity, formula...
